well, that's the way it's set... i'm not entirely sure what it means, but from what i read, CONFIG_PREEMPT being set would mean *anything* in the kernel can be preempted at *any* time, while CONFIG_PREEMPT_VOLUNTARY would mean that only code that calls something that says 'yes, from now on i will accept to be preempted' will be. or something.
that means normally that the application has to support/request pre-emp
someone said CONFIG_PREEMPT=y created problems with something-i-don't-remember, so i was curious as to the actual differences and advantages/disadvantages
pre-emp  can cause problem
oh. so the Ubuntu kernel *never* preempts unless there is an userlevel process asking it to?
